title: Of the Authority of General Councils
text: General Councils may not be gathered together without the commandment and will of Princes. And when they be gathered, they may err and sometimes have erred ... therefore they are not to be made the rule of faith ...
commentary: Article 21, “Of the Authority of General Councils”, states: General Councils may not be gathered together without the commandment and will of Princes. The commentary below is a concise study essay offering historical context, theological significance, and suggestions for further study. Historically this Article reflects the Reformation effort to retain the catholic tradition where it is scriptural while rejecting practices viewed as unscriptural. For modern readers, note how this Article shapes worship, preaching, and ethical teaching, and compare it with patristic sources and later Anglican commentators.
